Base Input: Can the court simply admit evidence of a fact based on its relevance, without first establishing the related fact as outlined by Rule 138(1) even if the evidence is hearsay?
Expected Output: Based on the provided context, the court can admit evidence of a fact solely based on its relevance, even if it's hearsay. However, the court must still determine if the proposed fact would be relevant before admitting it.  Rule 138(1) provides this discretion, as long as the fact is deemed relevant and not otherwise.
Retrieval Chunks String: Court to decide as to admissibility of evidence138.(1) When either party proposes to give evidence of any fact,the court may ask the party proposing to give the evidence in what manner the alleged fact, if proved, would be relevant; and the court shall admit the evidence if it thinks that the fact, if proved, would be relevant, and not otherwise.(2) If the fact proposed to be proved is one of which evidence is admissible only upon proof of some other fact, such last mentioned fact must be proved before evidence is given of the fact firstmentioned, unless the party undertakes to give proof of such fact and the court is satisfied with such undertaking.
